Robert Watkins wrote:

> I now have a new feature I want to write a test for. I look at the code, 
> notice that there is a private method that does that work - that's where 
> the new code will go. I can write a perfectly adequate test focused on 
> that private method alone - but I can't test private methods. So I 
> refactor to extract the method to an appropriate class (possibly new). I 
> run existing tests. I then write the test I _really_ want against the 
> newly exposed public method.

One thing strikes me about the arguments for making methods public. 
They're very much about the "I" or occasionally the "We". In other 
words, it's about convenience for the programmer doing the coding and 
writing the class library. By their role, this developer sees and needs 
to see everything in the classes, private and public. Because the class 
programmer's view of the class includes everything, the public-private 
distinction seems fairly unimportant.

Switch gears for a moment though, and consider the "them". In other 
words, think about the client programmer who uses the class but did not 
write it and doesn't want to write it.  What's important to them is that 
the class do what it promises to do in a straight-forward and obvious 
way. The more cluttered the class or library is with public methods, the 
harder it is to understand and use the class. The class user doesn't 
care if the code inside the class repeats itself or not. They don't care 
how difficult it was to test all the private methods. They only care if 
the class works in an intelligible way.

Every public method added to a class expands the complexity of the class 
more than linearly. Every public class added to a library expands the 
complexity of the library more than linearly. Usable APIs need to place 
the needs of the user ahead of the needs of the original developer. 
Simplicity is golden. Useful, usable APIs do one thing and do it well. 
They have a laserlike focus on a particular domain. They are not mere 
agglomerations of random utilities one programmer developed at one time 
or another throughout their career. For a practical example, XOM is a 
library for manipulating XML. Internally it's got a lot of code for 
handling URLs and URIs that was necessary to accomplish various XML 
tasks. However, none of this code is exposed in the public API because 
it's not about processing XML. Furthermore because it's not exposed it 
can take shortcuts and avoid edge conditions a fully general library 
would have to handle. It's faster and simpler because it does just what 
XOM needs and no more. A fully general URI library wouldn't have that 
advantage.

There's a real trade-off between making life easy for the developer or 
easy for the user, even when the user is a fellow developer. As the 
number of users grows relative to the number of developers, the 
cost-benefit ratio swings very much on the side of people writing the 
library doing more work so people merely using the library can do less.

Package private access is sometimes a reasonable compromise position. It 
lets the API-writer reuse their own code without making it public. 
Taking full advantage of package private in Java 5 and earlier requires 
not going overboard on package separation. In particular any sort of 
internal package that clients aren't supposed to touch is a code smell. 
Almost always the classes in these packages can and should be moved into 
non-public classes in the external packages.
